Technical Assistance 
Implementing Pilot Projects for Small Piped  
Water Networks 
(Cofinanced by the Government of France)
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During 2002 and 2003, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) carried out regional studies1 
on  small-scale  private  water  providers  (SSPWPs).  The  objectives  were  to  (i)  provide  an 
overview of urban water suppliers beyond formal water utilities, (ii) increase knowledge about 
the  type  of  services  provided  by  SSPWPs,  (iii)  define  the  profile  of  the  most  significant 
SSPWPs, and (iv) assess the main constraints on and potential of SSPWPs. The studies were 
carried out in Dhaka, Bangladesh; Shanghai, People’s Republic of China (PRC); Delhi, India; 
Jakarta, Indonesia; Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia; Kathmandu, Nepal; Manila and Cebu, Philippines; 
and Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam. 
 
2.  The results were published by ADB in 2004.2 The studies concluded that city officials, 
city water utilities, and local banks should work with small network entrepreneurs who can bring 
water supplies to the poor and disadvantaged immediately, on an agreed-upon interim basis 
until  the  water  utility  is  able  to  do  so.  These  small  networks  should  be  included  in  city 
development  strategies  and  formalized  with  licensing  and  exit  strategies  and  takeout 
agreements. Minimum standards should recognize risk and payback requirements. Enabling 
legal and contractual conditions should be created and small operators should be integrated into 
the water supply chain to the extent possible. Finally, the study concluded that ADB should join 
with two or three cities to test and refine these recommendations during 2005–2006. This 
technical assistance (TA), which is targeting three cities in three countries, will implement four 
pilot projects for small piped water networks (SPWNs) and water supply services surveys that 
will facilitate upscaling of the pilot projects.3 The ADB Fact-finding Mission visited the three 
countries in March–June 2005 and reached understandings with the governments concerned, 
local government representatives, potential nongovernment organization (NGO) participants, 
civil society stakeholders, and small-scale water providers (SSWPs) on the purpose, design, 
methodology, and implementing agencies for the TA. The TA design and monitoring framework 
is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  In the Asia and Pacific region, another 700 million people need to receive water supply 
to reach the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs).4 To achieve the MDG targets by 2015, 
many developing member countries (DMCs) acknowledge that it is important to reach Target 10 
on water and sanitation by 2010. The economic impact of improved piped water supply on 
health and education is significant.5 While ADB-supported projects in some DMCs, for example 
Phnom Penh in Cambodia and Dalian in the PRC, have achieved 24-hour water supply, many 
utilities in other DMCs have low levels of coverage. At five persons per connection, the effective 
coverage with piped connections in 20016 was 10% in Dhaka, 32% in Ho Chi Minh City, 31% in 
Jakarta, 32% in Manila, and 46% in Delhi. People who are not connected often pay water 
vendors about 15% of their household income for delivery of water, buying water from their

No.13, edited by Charles T. Andrews and Almud Weitz. ADB.

2   
neighbors at inflated cost, or getting water from standpipes or standposts where they have 
access to water for a very short time each day and have difficulty transporting it to their homes.  
 
4.  ADB publications (footnote 2) and experience of the World Bank and other agencies in 
Latin America and Africa reported that there are many issues  in addressing the immediate 
needs of the poor and those living in peri-urban areas, but the most typical are the following: (i) 
on the outskirts of a city, utility piped water is not close and SSWP has to put down a borehole 
and independently serve the people; (ii) the utility is in the area, but only serves through a 
standpipe/standpost;  by connecting to the utility, an SSWP can serve an area with direct house 
connections; (iii) on the outskirts of a city, the utility is not far away so the SSWP can connect to 
utility water and extend the piped supply farther out; and (iv) the utility is serving the people but 
the cost of connection is so high and the terms so steep that only half the people can afford to 
connect to piped water; thus, the homeowners association (HOA) is looking for better financing 
terms. All these four scenarios will be studied by the pilot projects of the TA. 
 
5.  In all cases, the core issue is getting connected to piped water, promptly and on terms 
affordable to those living in peri-urban areas, especially the poor. Once connected, people will 
pay only 1–2% of their household income for piped water. The implementation issue therefore is 
to find financing mechanisms that will be flexible and fast, and will respond to the needs of the 
people. With SPWNs, there is the case where financing is required by the contractor/operator; in 
another case financing is required by the HOA. With SSWPs, there is a need for regularization 
(maybe initially just by registration) and some control over the quality of construction and the 
responsibilities for operation and maintenance (O&M). 
 
6.  From ADB’s perspective, there is the bigger issue of reaching peri-urban consumers 
through piped water supply in an expeditious manner. In this regard, the potential for upscaling 
the pilot projects and mainstreaming and integrating SPWNs and SSWPs into both public and 
private sector loan projects will be important. These issues will be addressed by the TA. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome  
7.  The TA will enable selected urban population in India, Philippines, and Viet Nam to 
quickly connect to piped water supply. The TA aims to assist in achieving the MDG Target 10 on 
sustainable access to safe drinking water.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  The  TA  incorporates  five  strategic  approaches:  (i)  implementing  four  SPWN  pilot 
projects; (ii) setting up a registration system for SSWPs; (iii) preparing an evaluation report on 
the  implementation  of  the  four  SPWN  pilot  projects;  (iv)  organizing  regional  workshop  to 
disseminate evaluation report, and (v) developing a tool kit to replicate SPWN efforts. 
 
9.  Output 1. Implementing four SPWN pilot projects in Ahmedabad in Gujarat, India;7  
Kabisig and Lupang Arenda in Metro Manila, Philippines; and Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam. The 
four pilot areas were selected based on regional representation, diversity of issues, available 
                                                 
7  Two more pilot projects in the cities of Jabalpur and Indore in Madhya Pradesh are proposed for simultaneous 
implementation with UN-HABITAT parallel funding under the ongoing Water for Asian Cities Program. This 
program is implemented together with ADB’s Urban Water Supply and Environmental Improvement in Madhya 
Pradesh.

3
information,  and  the  potential  for  upscaling.  In  each  pilot  project,  the  community  will  be 
represented by an HOA or its equivalent.  
 
10.  In  the  Ho  Chi  Minh  City  pilot  project,  the  SSWP  has  already  developed  its  own 
groundwater source and has negotiated tariffs with the water utility for bulk sale of water to the 
utility as well as distribution to customers. In the other pilot projects, the water utility will be 
providing the water source and will sell the water in bulk to either the SSWP (Lupang Arenda) or 
the HOA (Kabisig) as the case may be. The bulk rate is expected to be an equivalent residential 
rate. The water utility will enter into a memorandum of agreement (MOA) with the SSWP or the 
HOA for a specific time, after which it agrees to take over full responsibility for the O&M of the 
facilities. The assets will, however, belong to the HOA or community who will have paid for them 
over a period of 5 years. The water utility or the relevant regulatory authority will be responsible 
for agreeing to the standard of construction to be used. 
 
11.  The SSWP will enter into an MOA with the local authority to construct the SPWN and 
operate and maintain it. The HOA shall nominate the SSWP. 
 
12.  A local bank or other suitable financial intermediary with a branch close to the pilot 
project will be nominated to be the recipient of the grant funds from ADB. The bank will onlend 
the money to the SSWP or HOA as the case may be.8 It will receive at least once a week all 
repayments of their loan from the SSWP or HOA, for SSWPs normally repay loans weekly, as 
poor consumers prefer to pay water tariffs daily or weekly. Once a month, the bank will report 
progress to ADB and continue to do so for a period of 5 years, being the maximum time for 
repayment of the original loans.9   
 
13.  All physical pipework for each pilot project will be completed within 8-10 months of 
commencing work. Except for the pilot project in India, each street will have a street meter and 
each household connection a house meter. As far as feasible, the SSWP or HOA will employ in 
the operation of the new system, including the daily collection of dues (except in Ho Chi Minh 
City), people such as water vendors who may have lost their job as a result of this intervention. 
Materials will be procured directly by the SSWP contractor or utility, based on the specifications 
approved for that specific location by the water utility or the regulatory body. 
 
14.  The scope of assistance comprises consulting services to train the HOAs and SSWPs in 
the construction and O&M of the new facilities. This assistance will be extended with the help of 
local government authorities, to all those who may at some time in the future take part in 
upscaling these activities. 
 
15.  ADB  will  request  a  no-objection  from  the  government  of  the  participating  countries 
before the TA is implemented. 
 
16.  Output 2. Setting up a registration system for existing SSWPs with the appropriate 
registering  agency.  To  assist  the  Government  in  registering  all  SSWPS  and  to  set  up  a

registration system, a comprehensive water supply service survey10 will be conducted, which 
will include all types of users, including commercial and industrial. On completion of the survey, 
the consultants will analyze the results and convene a stakeholder consultation, which will be 
the basis for formulating policy and plans and Government’s endorsement of providing further 
SPWN for communities not served by the formal water supply system. 
 
17.  Output 3. Evaluating the implementation of the four SPWN pilot projects. The evaluation 
report will (i) show how many people benefited, to what degree, at what unit cost; (ii) present 
how  quickly  the  project  was  implemented;  (iii)  identify  any  constraints  for  attention  during 
upscaling efforts; and (iv) assess replicability of the SPWN approach. It will also include the 
initial assessment of the performance of HOAs or SSWPs in implementing the new facilties.  
 
18.  Output 4. Organizing a regional workshop in Manila to disseminate the evaluation report 
to DMC key stakeholders to share their views, especially as to how best upscale the pilot 
projects and mainstream and integrate them into ADB lending.   
 
19.  Output 5. Developing a practical tool kit to help replicate efforts, and scale up SPWNs 
under ADB’s lending program to support DMCs to reach MDG Target 10. The tool kit will assist 
ADB staff in designing water supply projects. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
20.  The total cost of the project is estimated at $800,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed 
on a grant basis by (i) ADB’s TA funding program in the amount of $200,000 equivalent, and (ii) 
the Government of France in the amount of $200,000 equivalent, to be administered by ADB. 
The Cooperation Fund for the Water Sector through an approved TA11 will finance the remaining 
amount of $400,000 equivalent. HOAs will use their time and resources to help implement the 
pilot projects. In addition, government regulatory agencies will provide assistance in kind. The 
cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
21.  The TA will be implemented by ADB. The Energy, Transport, and Water Division (RSID) 
of  the  Regional  and  Sustainable  Development  Department,  in  cooperation  with  concerned 
divisions  in  the  regional  departments  and  the  ADB  resident  missions  concerned,  will  be 
responsible for all TA activities. A TA office will be established in RSID.  
 
22.  A total of 30 person-months of domestic consultants will be needed for implementation. 
In  each  of  the  three  participating  countries,  one  community-based  water  supply  specialist 
(domestic consultant) will supervise the implementation of the pilot projects, and a regulatory 
specialist (domestic consultant) will be responsible for the conduct of the water services survey 
in each city. One water supply and sanitation specialist (domestic consultant) based in Manila 
will coordinate all TA activities. The local banks or other city-based financial intermediaries in 
each pilot project will provide training on billing and collection of dues and basic financial 
analysis for the communities and the SSWPs. The concerned water utility will give advice on 
construction and O&M of the facilities. An expert on water supply and sanitation (international

water quality, reliability of supply, and the type of household sanitation.

5
consultant) will be engaged for 1 person-month to research and summarize other SSWP studies 
and interventions (including those funded by the Water and Sanitation Program in Jakarta, 
AusAID in Manila, and UN-HABITAT in Africa). This consultant will also assist in organizing and 
conducting the regional workshop. The required consultants will be recruited as individuals in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other terms acceptable to 
ADB for engaging domestic consultants. The outline terms of reference for consulting services 
is in Appendix 3.12 
 
23.  Materials and equipment to implement the pilot projects will be procured following ADB’s 
Guidelines for Procurement and other terms acceptable to ADB for the engagement of domestic 
consultants. 
 
24.  The TA will be implemented in 24 months, starting in November 2005 and ending in  
October 2007. The pilot projects will be evaluated after the pilots have been in operation for 6 
months. The regional workshop will be held in August 2007. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
25.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $200,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Government of France; and (ii) ADB providing the balance not 
exceeding the equivalent of $200,000 on a grant basis for Implementing Pilot Projects for Small 
Piped Water Networks, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
                                                 
12  External to this TA, an expert on water sector evaluation (international consultant), funded by the ADB Water 
Cooperation Fund and employed by RSID will evaluate the pilot projects and conduct a regional workshop in 
Manila to discuss and disseminate the findings. This consultant will compile a tool kit for upscaling the pilot projects 
for mainstreaming and integration into ADB’s lending program.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  General   
1.  Consulting services are required in four main areas. One water and sanitation specialist 
(domestic consultant) as technical assistance (TA) coordinator is required in Manila to oversee 
and coordinate the implementation of the pilot projects. One community-based water supply 
specialist (domestic consultant) is required in each of the three participating countries to assist 
in  implementing  the  pilot  projects  in  those  countries.  The  community-based  water  supply 
specialists will also be responsible for training the small-scale water providers (SSWPs) or 
homeowners association (HOAs) in operations and maintenance (O&M) of the new facilities. A 
regulatory specialist (domestic consultant) in each of the three participating countries will work 
with the regulatory agency to survey and register all small-piped water networks (SPWNs), 
HOAs, and SSWPs. 
 
B.  TA Coordinator (6 person-months) 
2.  The  TA  coordinator,  based  in  Manila  at  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB) 
headquarters as part of the water team, will have overall responsibility for monitoring and 
reporting on the implementation of the TA. He/she will report to the senior water supply and 
sanitation specialist of Energy, Transport and Water Division (RSID). More specifically, he/she 
will prepare documents for procurement materials and equipment and to contract SSWPS or 
HOAs. The coordinator will undertake (i) official progress reporting communication on a weekly 
basis with the three consultants assisting in pilot project implementation, (ii) official progress 
reporting communication on a weekly basis with the three consultants assisting in the survey 
and registration of SSWPs and HOAs, and (iii) official progress reporting communication on a 
weekly basis with the local banks associated with the receipt and disbursement of funds for the 
pilot projects. The coordinator will summarize all this information on a weekly basis in one 
weekly report and discuss it with the senior water supply and sanitation specialist at RSID. If 
necessary, the coordinator will communicate back to the consultants in the field and to the 
banks feedback and advice from ADB regarding any constraints or issues in implementation. 
The coordinator will help ADB organize and conduct the concluding regional workshop to be 
held in Manila in August 2007. 
 
C.  Community-Based Water Supply Specialists (3 consultants, 4 person-months each) 
3.  Each consultant will assist the SSWPs and HOAs in implementing the pilot project. 
He/she will submit to the TA coordinator weekly progress monitoring reports that will include 
information on the (i) implementation of the work plan and the latest revised schedule, (ii) 
activities carried out during the last week and by whom, (iii) activities planned for the next week 
and by whom, (iv) constraints encountered and what action is being taken to overcome them, 
and (v) issues that need discussion or resolution. For each pilot project, this consultant must 
communicate daily with the appropriate representatives of the community, the contractor and 
the water provider as well as the local bank. Once a week, all these people should meet 
formally to discuss the progress of the pilot project with the officer of the government regulatory 
agency present. The consultant will take the minutes of this meeting and forward them to the TA 
coordinator in Manila (via e-mail) with his/her own comments appended. This consultant will 
train the SSWP or HOAs in O&M of the completed facilities until such time as they are taken 
over by the water utility. The training participants will include those designated from within the 
pilot project area, as well as representatives of the project area that will be involved in any later 
upscaling of the pilot projects. Two trainees are required from each pilot project: a technical

10  Appendix 3 
person for supervising any construction and undertaking any maintenance, and a financial 
person for recording consumption and payment on a daily basis and remitting payments to the 
local bank. Within the first month of the assignment, the consultant will propose a training plan 
that will need to be endorsed by the community, the SSWP, the water utility, and the local bank 
before being submitted to ADB for approval. It is envisaged that technical and financial training 
will each comprise a total of 15 hours spread over at least 5 days.  With ADB’s approval, the 
consultant may engage, on an honorarium basis, other experts from the local bank or water 
utility to assist in the training. 
 
D.  Regulatory Specialists (3 consultants, 4 person-months each) 
4.  Each consultant will assist the government regulatory agency to survey, and record and 
register all SSWPs and HOAs involved in providing water. To be included are not only those 
engaged in constructing and operating SPWNs but also those operating tanker services or 
tricycle or pushcart water vendors selling water by the container. The TA provides separate 
monies  for  conducting  these  surveys,  but  the  consultant,  in  close  cooperation  with  the 
regulatory agency, needs to help design the surveys, help train people involved in undertaking 
the surveys, independently monitor the validity of the information returned from the surveys, and 
collate the information received into one easily read and understood report. The consultant 
should analyze the information and write a brief summary report of about 10 pages to be 
attached to the basic data report. The consultant will assist the regulatory agency in designing a 
simple one-page registration form appropriate to the SSWP, be it a SPWN, delivery by tanker or 
by container as the case may be. The consultant will report to the TA coordinator in Manila once 
a week on progress with the surveys. 
 
E.  International Consultant (1 person-month) 
5.  An international consultant will be engaged to undertake, on an intermittent basis, two 
tasks: (i) research and summarize, for the regional consultation workshop, other activities and 
studies on SSWPs and SPWN financing from Africa, Asia, and Latin America; and  (ii) assist in 
designing and conducting the regional workshop consultation, contribute to the discussions, and 
record the procedures for publication.  
 
F.  Implementation by Nongovernment Organizations (NGOs) 
6.  For the pilot project in Ahmedabad, India, a consortium of three NGOs will implement the 
pilot project in a slum, and carry out the water supply services survey, analyze the findings, 
convene  a  stakeholders’  workshop,  and  register  the  SSWPs.  The  NGOs  will  be  engaged 
following ADB’s guidelines on direct selection in consultation with local government authorities. 
Overall supervision of the project will be through one individual pilot project consultant as above.
